The Afghanistan National Development Strategy (ANDS), launched 
by the Government in April 2008, is the country’s strategic platform 
for  development  during  2008–2020.  Its  aim  is  to  promote  growth, 
generate  wealth,  and  reduce  poverty  and  vulnerability.  ANDS 
covers  all  key  sectors  and  subsectors,  and  embraces  several 
themes.  One  of  the  main  sectors  is  energy.  ANDS  establishes 
quantitative  and  qualitative  (physical  and  nonphysical)  targets,  and 
covers generation, transmission, and distribution. Within the sector, 
ANDS  covers  investments  in  new  and  existing  assets,  including 
their  management,  maintenance,  and  repair.  The  underlying 
objective  is  to  provide  reliable  and  cost-effective  electricity  to 
industry  and  people.  The  proposed  MFF  finances  a  medium-term 
slice  of  a  broader  Investment  Program.  It  is  also  consistent  with 
ADB’s  strategy  for  the  country  articulated  in  the  Country  Strategy

power and energy, and irrigation. The Government also wants ADB

transactions.  The  ADB  strategy  responds  to  what  the  Government 
needs, and focuses in areas where ADB has skills, knowledge and

The  PMO  will  require  consulting  services.  Firms  and  individuals 
(national  and  international)  will  be  engaged  to  provide  advisory 
services  in  the  following  areas:  (i) project  management;  (ii)  due

design  engineering,  procurement,  and  supervision;  (iv) safeguard 
management  and  gender  mainstreaming; 
(v)  evaluation, 
monitoring,  auditing,  reporting,  and  measuring  results;  and  (vi) 
training  and  policy  advice.  Consultants  will  be  selected  and 
engaged  in  accordance  with  ADB’s  Guidelines  on  the  Use  of 
Consultants using the quality-based selection method.  
 
Single-source  selection  may  be  used  to  recruit  a  consultant  to 
help  with  the  Sheberghan  Gas  Fields  Rehabilitation  Project.  The 
least-cost  selection  method  will  be  used  to  recruit  external 
auditors  and  external  agencies  to  monitor  the  implementation  of 
safeguards.  Individual  consultants  may  be  recruited  for  other 
assignments, in accordance with ADB procedures for recruitment 
of individual consultants.  
 
The  Investment  Program  will  benefit  people  and  businesses. 
Benefits  are  derived  from  the  provision  of  less-expensive  and 
more reliable electricity to a greater number of people for most of 
the  year.  Energy  will  improve  welfare  and  accelerate  economic 
growth.  The  Investment  Program  will  also  have  gender-related 
benefits,  particularly  as  household  tasks  become  less  labor 
intensive  and  job  opportunities  grow.  Household  will  benefit  by 
reducing  the  use  of  expensive  diesel-generated  electricity.  The 
Investment Program will have minimal impact on the environment. 
In addition to initiating environmental due diligence the Investment 
Program will take a broader view on climate change, particularly in 
the  context  of  energy  conservation,  clean  energy,  renewable 
energy, and system efficiency. 
 
The  key  assumptions  for  success  of  the  Investment  Program 
include  (i)  timely  implementation  of  projects,  (ii)  more  effective 
the  policy 
institutions,  (iii)  a  commitment 
framework,  (iv)  stable  regulation  arrangements  and  tariff  regime, 
and (v) improvement in security. 
 
One  of  the  main  risks  to  the  Investment  Program  is  that  the 
restructuring  of  DABS  could  be  delayed  or  not  be  completed. 
Other  risks  include  insufficient  power  imports  from  neighboring 
countries and inadequate project management.  
 
The  modernization  of  DABS  is  on  course,  although  the  process 
will  require  a  major  political  commitment  and  working  capital 
financing  in  the  short  term.  Considerable  technical  assistance  is 
being assigned to this task from ADB and other agencies such as 
the  World  Bank.  Electricity  supplies  from  Uzbekistan  are  not 
formally  confirmed,  although  both  parties  have  been  talking

The establishment of the PMO breaks with past practice, taking a 
holistic view of the management of project tasks and themes.

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

A. 
 
Devastated  by  decades  of  conflict,  Afghanistan  has  one  of  the  lowest  electrification 
2. 
ratios  and  energy  consumption  rates  in  the  world.  An  estimated  9%  of  the  population  has 
access  to  intermittent  public  power,  and  per  capita  electricity  consumption  is  as  low  as  21 
kilowatt-hours (kWh) per year. Cities such as Kabul, the capital, get electricity only 2–3 hours a 
day.  The  shortage  of  electricity  affects  people  in  urban  and  rural  areas  alike.  It  is  a  binding 
constraint on development.  
 
3. 
The Government wants to reverse the situation and has given top priority to the energy 
sector  in  its  midterm  development  program.  This  is  reflected  in  the  Afghanistan  National 
Development  Strategy  (ANDS), 1  which  was  approved  in  April  2008  and  submitted  to  the 
international community in Paris in mid-2008. The ANDS calls for investments in infrastructure 
in general, but particularly for energy security. Achieving energy security will require expanding 
and  improving  transmission  and  distribution  networks,  and  increasing  domestic  generation 
capacity by using a mix of hydro and thermal power resources. This will not be straightforward, 
because  (i)  the  power  system  is  underdeveloped  and  the  existing  facilities  are  in  a  state  of 
disrepair (some facilities are well beyond their economic life), (ii) the private sector is too small 
and uninterested in backing such large investments, and  (iii) foreign investors are deterred by 
the deteriorating security situation. This places the responsibility mainly on a weak public sector. 
Generating  more  power  domestically  will  take  time.  An  interim  measure  is  to  import  electricity 
from neighboring countries. Both the importation of electricity and the development of domestic 
capacity  will  require  the  expansion  and  improvement  of  the  transmission  and  distribution 
systems.  
 
4. 
A  flagship  investment  is  already  in  place:  the  new  220-kilovolt  (kV)  North  East  Power 
System  (NEPS)  that  connects  Kabul,  Pul-e-Khumri,  Mazar-e-Sharif,  Kunduz,  and  other  load 
centers  of  northern  and  eastern  Afghanistan.  This  investment  is  vital  for  power  imports  from 
Tajikistan and Uzbekistan (and later from Turkmenistan). The most important parts of the NEPS 
are being completed. A transmission line in Uzbekistan to connect to NEPS, scheduled to come 
on stream in May 2009, will initially enable 150 MW of power to be supplied to Kabul and other 
centers around NEPS.  
 
5. 
Afghanistan Electricity Corporation (DABS), established in March 2008, will be the major 
player in the industry. The former Afghanistan Electricity Organization (DABM), a department of 
the Ministry of Energy and Water (MEW), is being transformed into a new company, DABS, with 
its  own  statutes,  a  business  strategy  and  mandate,  and  an  independent  management  team. 
DABS  is  a  vertically  integrated  national  power  utility  that  will  own  and  operate  generation,

Afghanistan, the probability of the company remaining vertically integrated is high. Since nearly 
80% of energy consumption in Afghanistan is in the form of electricity, this transformation—and 
later  the  introduction  of  better  operating  practices  at  DABS—represents  an  essential  first  step 
toward  improving  the  organization  of  the  sector.  The  outcome  must  reduce,  and  eventually 
eliminate,  a  binding  constraint  to  economic  growth  in  Afghanistan  by  producing,  transmitting, 
and  distributing  more  electricity  for  more  hours  each  day  to  more  people  and  businesses  in  a 
cost-effective  and  efficient  manner.  However,  even  after  the  transformation  of  DABS  into  a 
company, the tasks ahead are difficult due to the complex issues that need to be resolved. 
 
6. 
The  main  challenges  are  to  put  in  place  a  professional  and  experienced  management 
team,  enough  working  capital  and  development  financing,  tighter  governance  systems,  and  a 
sound tariff regime to support operations. DABS will need to spin off some of its activities inherited 
from DABM, refocus its strategy and business plan on priority areas, and develop partnerships with 
local  and  international  entities.  Energy  security  will  be  a  function  of  how  well  DABS  addresses 
those issues. DABS will need enormous support over the short to medium term.  
 
7. 
The  country  has  natural  gas,  coal,  and  hydropower  potential.  Gas  and  coal  resources 
have been identified mostly in central and northern Afghanistan. However, the lack of long-term 
funding  to  rehabilitate  dilapidated  infrastructure,  or  to  investigate  and  develop  reserves,  limits 
their viability. Exploration of indigenous resources and development of hydropower potential will 
strengthen domestic generation and improve energy security. In the meantime, the country will 
have to rely on imported power and fuels. The recent international price increases for both were 
huge shocks for an already shaky economy and emphasized the importance of energy security.  
 
8. 
The Investment Program is driven by the country’s strategic directions for the sector and 
by a policy framework calling for greater operational and institutional efficiency, cost recovery, 
competition,  transparency,  and  good  governance.  The  strategy  is  clear.  The  policy  framework 
needs some refinements, especially regarding the tariff regime, aspects of the legal framework, 
divestment,  and  the  energy  mix.  This  work  will  require  major  assistance.  These  shortcomings 
must  not  stop  the  development  of  strategic  investments.  The  investment  plan  includes  short-, 
medium-,  and  long-term  investments,  and  blends  physical  with  nonphysical  interventions.  As 
such, the timing of the ADB assistance makes sense.

Underdeveloped  and  Inefficient  Transmission  System.  The  transmission  system  is

12. 
Underdeveloped  and  Poorly  Managed  Distribution  System.  The  Government  and 
the  development  community  has  funded  major  rehabilitation  and  expansion  works  directed  at

distribution  networks  in  areas  outside  NEPS  need  to  be  expanded  and  rehabilitated.  Many 
facilities  were  destroyed  during  the  conflict;  others  have  exhausted  their  economic  life.  This 
leads  to  system  inefficiencies,  including  high  technical  losses  and  poor  customer  service  in 
terms of coverage, quality, and consistency.  
 
13. 
High Losses. Total losses including technical losses are estimated at 30% of generated 
electricity.  A  10%  loss  is  probably  acceptable  under  the  conditions  in  Afghanistan,  but  the

financial problems and limited electricity coverage. Unless the situation is addressed, it will put 
DABS’s  financial  sustainability  at  risk.  It  will  undermine  its  ability  to  service  consumers  and 
make future investments. The alternative is rising subsidies and a deteriorating fiscal situation. 
The budget is already stressed because of declining tax revenues.  
 
14. 
Limited Rural Energy and Geographical Electrification Coverage. Many parts of the 
country do not have any electricity service coverage. Where there is coverage, the systems are 
poorly  maintained.  The  multi  aid  agency-funded  National  Solidarity  Program  (NSP),  managed

electrification. The NSP supports electrification schemes with installed capacity typically below 
25 kilowatts (kW). Although this fills only a small part of the energy gap in these areas, it is a 
good  initiative.  Larger  schemes  are  planned,  but  most  have  not  come  on  stream.  The 
Renewable  Energy  and  Rural  Electrification  Subcommittee  was  established  under  the  Inter-

where the bulk of the population lives.

is considering rehabilitating domestic gas wells, which would improve the gas supply to consumers,

17.  Weak  Legal  and  Regulatory  Framework.  Many  institutions  are  engaged  in  different

of DABM into DABS is a positive step, but more work is needed to see that it succeeds. High levels

The  Afghanistan  energy  sector  strategy  is  a  by-product  of  ANDS  and  was  formulated 
23.

Afghanistan. The main benefits accruing from the investment are tangible; others are not. Some

II.  Grant Development Objectives and Expected Key Performance Indicators 

Grant  Development  Objectives:  The  Project’s  objective  is  to  improve  the  quality  of  life  of  rural 
communities  in  Badakhshan  and  Bamyan  provinces  through  the  provision  of  electricity  services 
supplied by mini hydropower plants (MHP) with generating capacity below 1,000 kilowatts (kW). 

The Project outcome will include: (i) provision of affordable and stable electricity, (ii) increase in rural 
commercial  activities  from  establishment  of  enterprises  using  electricity,  (iii)  increased  employment 
opportunities, (iv) reduction of indoor pollution caused by the use of indigenous sources of energy, and 
(v) capacity building in small hydropower development. 

The Project outputs are the identification, planning, designing, and establishment of a maximum of four 
off-grid MHPs, each with an installed capacity in the order of magnitude of 500 kW. Target areas are 
district centers that are not planned for grid connection in the foreseeable future or are being supplied 
through  expensive  and  unreliable  diesel  generation.  Communities  will  receive  support  to  establish 
income-generating activities during the day-time (i.e., off-peak hours). 

The  MHPs  will  be  operated  and  maintained  by  the  Afghanistan  Electricity  Corporation  (DABS),  the 
national  power  utility.  To  ensure  sustainable  management,  capacity  building  is  integrated  as  an 
essential  component  of  the  Project.  Similarly,  the  entire  project  cycle  is  regarded  as  an  on-the-job 
training opportunity in which counterpart staff of the Executing Agency, DABS, will be closely engaged 
in subproject preparation and implementation.

1. Key Issues  
The  continuing  state  of  conflict  in  Afghanistan  has  resulted  in  deteriorating  systems  for  energy  transmission  and

Supporting better efficiency of the sector and improving access are expected to ensure a reliable supply to multiple

Internal Monitoring 

21. 
The PMO, through the ESU, will routinely carry out internal monitoring, and the results 
will  be  communicated  to  ADB  through  the  quarterly  project  implementation  reports.  Indicators 
related to the process, immediate outputs, and results will be used for internal monitoring. This 
information will be collected directly from the field and reported monthly to the PMO to assess 
the  progress  and  results  of  LAR  plan  implementation,  and  to  adjust  the  work  program  if 
necessary. The monthly reports will be consolidated every quarter in the standard supervision 
reports  and  submitted  to  ADB.  The  following  will  be  monitoring  benchmarks:  (i)  information 
campaign and consultation with affected persons, (ii) status of land acquisition and payments on 
land compensation, (iii) compensation for affected structures and other assets, (iv) relocation of 
affected persons, (v) payments for loss of income, (vi) selection and distribution of replacement 
land, and (vii) income-restoration activities.

External Monitoring 

22. 
External monitoring will be carried out twice a year, and the results will be communicated 
to  the  PMO  and  ADB  through  semiannual  reports.  The  EMA  will  be  recruited  annually  on  an 
intermittent  basis  up  to  1  year  after  the  project  works  are  completed.  The  EMA  will  also  be 
responsible for (i) issuing a no-objection certification to proceed with work in sections of lots of 
the project where there is no land acquisition; and (ii) for sections or lots where LAR is required, 
completing  an  audit  confirming  that  all  compensation  and  related  resettlement  assistance  in 
cash  or  kind  has  been  delivered  to  the  affected  households  before  issuing  no-objection  to 
proceed.  A  copy  of  the  no-objection  certificate  will  be  submitted  to  the  PMO  (ESU), 
implementation consultant, and ADB simultaneously.  
 
23. 
The EMA will also assess the status of vulnerable groups affected by the project, such 
as  households  headed  by  women,  disabled  and/or  elderly  and  poor  families.  The  indicators 
developed  for  monitoring  and  evaluation  of  the  project  will  be  based  on  the  following:  (i) 
socioeconomic  conditions  of  the  affected  persons  after  resettlement;  (ii)  communications  and 
reactions  from  affected  persons  on,  among  other  things,  entitlements,  compensation,  options, 
alternative developments, and relocation timetables; (iii) changes in housing and income levels; 
(iv)  rehabilitation  of  squatters;  (v)  valuation  of  property;  (vi)  grievance  procedures;  (vii) 
disbursement  of  compensation;  and  (viii)  level  of  satisfaction  of  affected  persons  after 
resettlement. 
 
24. 
For each project, the EMA will carry out an evaluation of the LAR plan about 1 year after 
its  implementation.  The  main  reason  for  this  study  is  to  find  out  whether  the  plan  objectives 
were  attained.  The  socioeconomic  survey  baseline  will  be  used  to  compare  pre-  and  post-
project conditions. The EMA will recommend supplemental assistance for the affected persons if 
the study shows that the objectives of the LAR plan have not been attained.
